More questions today...

First question. I've never picked up on this before, but realized that both NAMBAN and NANBAN is used with describing these tsuba. Is there a simple explanation for this? 

Second question. What is the difference between the carving techniques, SUKIDASHI-BORI and SUKISAGE-BORI? My translated texts use the term sukisage-bori but glossaries seem to only define sukidashi-bori. I'm suspecting they describe the same technique of producing low relief by carving away the tsuba's surface metal. 

Just more confusion discovered when writing was was to be a simple, straight-forward namban tsuba article. (sigh)

P.S. I'd like to ask Jim Gilbert a question. Jim, are you out there???

Ron
STL
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: JAYDC1388@... 
  To: token_kenkyu_kai@... 
  Sent: Tuesday, July 27, 2010 9:24 PM
  Subject: Re: Name this dragon...


  Hi Ron,
  Really neat tsuba, I believe these are water dragons the way they are done in Hizen style, I found a couple links below:


  this one has the closest silhouette  but yours has more detail

  http://www.nihonto.com.au/html/tsu039_hizen_dragon_0.html


  click on zoom I  think you can make out the beard 
  http://www.worthpoint.com/worthopedia/1021-jp-samurai-sword-water-dragon-menuki



  Pretty positive this is the right type of dragon. I'm sure your library is way superior to mine, and this will help point in the the right direction.  

  Regards,
  Lance
